setup.question: Which of these sets of descriptions best describes Peggy?

Text.text: Both are possible.

Peggy is an aspiring actress who wants to go to the big city at any cost necessary, in doing so she tries to convince her parents to send her to New York however the only issue is that she is definitely not ready. She eventually hatches a plan to go to New York and fulfill some of their wishes so that she can go act and is creative in how she gets her  plan to work. She is talented as revealed by her friend Jean as well. However it's important to analyze her character through her actions not what people say about her.

Peggy is a young woman who wants to move to NYC to pursue acting, something her parents are initially worried about but come to enthusiastically support by the end of the story.

she has been dedicated to acting for a long time:
Pretty:
Bold: It's cliché, but she is ready to leave everything she knows for her dream:
Just to hedge: I think there is support for her being talented, and probably creative too, but little to support that she is unwise.

For A, I think the evidence for talented is sufficient.
For B, I think the evidence for pretty is sufficient.

As always, if you have issues with opposing evidence or characterization, be sure to supply the needed context.
A: Can you dive more into her misadventures and prove that she is unwise and not ready?
B: For dedicated, she's been wanting a break for years, but do you have any stronger evidence via her actions on how she's dedicated herself to her craft?
Peggy is a little bit of a whiner her father says
and she responds
her father interjects that there are other subjects to explore

it is clear that she is unwise and has a poor world view due to lack of exposure and over indulgent parents. Just because her parents say she is "talented" doesn't actually mean she is, further B cites evidence of her being pretty as a description curly hair and hazel eyes which doesn't necessarily mean someones pretty it is literally just a description.
Re dedicated: Sure, it's not just that she's wanted a break. To be successful, she is willing to put in a lot of work:
, and if that doesn't immediately go well then she'll work

while she waits for parts.

Furthermore, she's not at all unwise. She recognizes that being an actress isn't a guaranteed thing, and she says that if it doesn't work out she will
. Her mother recognizes this:
. By the end of the story, her father agrees, and both her parents are supportive of her decision!
New judge here: I agree'd with the first judgement, but this new evidence is more persuasive for B. If there aren't any glaring flaws, I'll probs vote B!
disproves pretty
her creative attempt at the plan to let her go to new york

but even after this her dad asks her "But are you so confident that you'll see results in one year?"(have ev) because even in her creative plan she is still banking on fame happening in a year, not to mention she talks about working in an office while waiting for parts INSTEAD of going to school like her parents had been advocating for. While she may have the talent and charm to get her goal she makes her decision rashly

I'm not sure why A thinks that "gaining character" means that she isn't pretty, but it is true that she's no longer a young girl. She's college-aged, and now thinks she should play roles that reflect that. Her friend Jean thinks that Peggy is pretty:

.

Her father ends up agreeing with her:

. It's true that her parents are skeptical, at first. I've never challenged that. But they agree that she has thought it through enough to understand the challenge–far from unwise or "rash"!

Judge: vote for B.

Slightly moved in favor of B, partially for the clarity of their arguments, also because A's evidence for her not being pretty is very unconvincing IMO. However, she does sound creative, and I could still see her decision to pursue acting being unwise if I was given more context than I have, so I can't be certain yet.

So currently I'm basically only unconvinced that she's unwise, but I'm pretty convinced of all of B's properties. This represents about half of my 20% move in favor of B, the other half coming largely from A's bad evidence against her being pretty.

this is a reasonable request on behalf of peggys parents who all throughout the story indulge in her acting dreams and while they think she is talented and its important to note that these are biased sources her own parents are telling her this so keep that in mind for both A and B

howev, she legit says that

are all not as important or fascinating to her (open quotes tab and you'll see) this is not the words of someone who is wise or balanced, this is someone who is letting their emotions get the best of them

the story follows Peggy + her parents as she tries to convince them that she is both talented enough to pursue acting and thoughtful enough to make that decision soundly. It's true her parents are skeptical of her at the beginning of the story. However, she assuages these fears by promising to go back and get her teaching degree if she can't make it work: (already given in ev +

)

This convinces her parents that she has actually thought about this!
ALSO: A is lying about those one-word lines, which are from her FATHER, NOT PEGGY

UGH. Both A and B's new quotes are persuasive. The quotes about specific subjects are unconvincing, however (just b/c she isn't interested in them as much as acting doesn't mean she's unwise, especially given all of the evidence of her reasonableness that B has presented. However, B's point about A lying about the subjects makes me DISTRUST B, because I don't think A was trying to lie/mislead - who said the names of the subjects is immaterial for the question of whether she said that those subjects aren't as important to her as acting, which is all A said. I think this is probably just a slight mistake on B's part though, given all of the evidence they've presented of her reasonableness, and A's inability to disprove any of B's properties.

answers.other: I'm confused by the judge's reasoning about my point that A misattributes quotes. A's contention is that Peggy says those things are unimportant, and I claim (correctly) that she never says this, and that A's quotes are sourced from her father. Judge's reasoning for this being distrustful on my part doesn't make sense.
answers.reason for outcome: I was honest and had decent textual support for my side

I think i should have maybe put better arguments ouyt in the beginning the only reason the judge thinks im more convincing this time around is cause the other quotes were finally contextuakized in my last speech, i wish there was an opprtunity for me to include more quotes so that i can present a cohesive argument up front
